source_note: State baseline derived from Michigan EGLE recycling and solid waste guidance; local collection rules vary.

organics.guidance: Composting of food and yard waste allowed under EGLE rules; many municipalities operate yard waste programs.
organics.notes: Ann Arbor and Grand Rapids offer curbside composting.

paper_cardboard.guidance: Recycle clean, dry paper and cardboard; flatten before recycling.

glass_containers.guidance: Recycle bottles and jars (rinsed, no lids).
glass_containers.notes: Not all curbside programs accept glass.

metal_containers.guidance: Recycle clean aluminum and steel/tin cans.
metal_containers.notes: No scrap metal or aerosol cans.

plastics.guidance: Recycle bottles, jugs, and tubs labeled #1–#7 depending on local program.
plastics.notes: Plastic film and foam not accepted curbside.

beverage_containers_crv.guidance: Michigan has a 10¢ beverage container deposit law (Bottle Bill).
beverage_containers_crv.notes: Covers aluminum, glass, and plastic drink containers.

household_batteries.guidance: Recycle rechargeable and lead-acid batteries through Call2Recycle or HHW events.

e_waste.guidance: Electronics recycling supported by EGLE partnerships and local events.
e_waste.notes: Accepted items vary; TVs may have fees.

plastic_bags_and_film.guidance: Plastic bags and film not accepted in curbside recycling.
plastic_bags_and_film.notes: Film creates contamination issues at MRFs.

bulky_items.guidance: Bulky items must be taken to landfill or scheduled for pickup.
bulky_items.notes: Fees and rules vary by city.
